turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Just as I suspected, wise guy! I don't mind you making a sap out of yourself - but you made one out of me, too.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Will you tell the gentleman I'm not in?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Mary Dawson, huh? Mary Dawson, my eye. That dame took you for a sleigh ride that New York will laugh about for years. She's the slickest, two- timing, double-crossing

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: She's the star reporter on The Mail. Every time you opened your kisser, you gave her another story. She's the dame who slapped that monicker on you - "Cinderella Man." You've been making love to a double dose of cyanide!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: You shouldn't be running away like this. What's going to happen to the Estate?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: They can have the Estate.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: What about your knocking off for lunch?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Not hungry. I want to get through this work in a hurry, and then I want to go home. What price did you get on those trucks?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Come on, come on. What are you trying to do, kid? Keel over? You haven't been out of this house in two weeks.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, maybe I will have a sandwich.  Do you mind waiting a few minutes?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Cobb! Get lunch for the rest of them.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: What? There must be 2000 of them out there.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, that doesn't make 'em any less hungry.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Okay, Santa Claus. 2000 lunches.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'm Chairman?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: Oh Yes, of course - you've just been elected.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'm Chairman.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Wait a minute. What does the Chairman do?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: Why, the Chairman presides at the meetings.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That's what I thought. If you don't mind, I'm rather interested in the Treasurer's report. I'd like to hear it.

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not conducted for profit.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: It isn't? What is it conducted for?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: Why, it's an artistic institution

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: We own an opera house, don't we?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: We provide opera.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: But you charge. I mean, you sell tickets?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: That's impossible. The opera has never paid.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, then, we must give the wrong kind of shows.

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: The wrong kind! There isn't any wrong or right kind. Opera is opera!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I guess it is. But I personally wouldn't care to be head of a business that kept losing money. That wouldn't be common sense. Incidentally, where is the $180,000 coming from?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: Well, we were rather expecting it to come from you.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Me?!

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: Naturally.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Excuse me, gentlemen, there's nothing natural about that .

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Now, where were we?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not conducted like any ordinary business.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: DOUGLAS
turns.text: Because it just isn't a business, that's all!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, maybe it isn't to you, but it certainly is a business to me, if I have to make up a loss of $180,000. If it's losing that much money, there must be something wrong. Maybe you charge too much. Maybe you're selling bad merchandise. Maybe lots of things. I don't know. You see, I expect to do a lot of good with that money. And I can't afford to put it into anything that I don't look into. That's my decision for the time being, gentlemen. Goodbye, and thank you for making me Chairman.

turns.speaker: VON HOLLER
turns.text: You remember, Dr. Fosdick, in my last book there are some very fine examples.

turns.speaker: DR. FOSDICK
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: VON HOLLER
turns.text: Especially, the one of the young nobleman, you remember?

turns.speaker: DR. FOSDICK
turns.text: Oh, yes. Yes, of course Dr. Von Holler. Very interesting.

turns.speaker: VON HOLLER
turns.text: It reminds me very much of this one. Nicht wahr?

turns.speaker: DR. FOSDICK
turns.text: Ja.

turns.speaker: VON HOLLER
turns.text: It takes so long to detect them  because their mood changes so often and so quickly. Now, Your Honor, may I show you? May I use the chart?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Let him alone.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Let me alone!  If you know what's good for you - you'll let me get this off my chest!  How did you feel feeding doughnuts to a horse?  Get a kick out of it, huh? Got a big laugh?  Did you ever think of feeding doughnuts to human beings! No!

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Yeah - that's all that's worrying you. What do I want?  A chance to feed a wife and kids! I'm a farmer. A job! That's what I want!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: A farmer, eh! You're a moocher, that's what you are! I wouldn't believe you or anybody else on a stack of bibles! You're a moocher like all the rest of them around here, so get out of here!

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Sure - everybody's a moocher to you. A mongrel dog eating out of a garbage pail is a moocher to you!

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Here's the order for the plows. We got a good price on them.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That's fine. Thanks. I'll look 'em over later.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Deeds

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: my wife wanted me to tell you she  she prays for you every night.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, thanks, I - uh  How do you do? What is your name?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Mrs. Semple?

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Yes. Your uncle's common-law wife. She has a legal claim on the estate.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: I leave it to you, Mr. Deeds. Can you conceive of any court not being in sympathy with any woman who gave up the best years of her life for an old man like your uncle?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What kind of wife did you say she was?

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Common-law wife. On top of that, there's a child.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: A child? My uncle's?

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That's awful. The poor woman should be taken care of immediately.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: I'm glad to see you're willing to be reasonable, Mr. Deeds.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: If she was his wife, she should have all the money. That's only fair. I don't want a penny of it.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Well, what about it, Mr. Deeds?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You'll excuse me, won't you? I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sorry to keep you waiting so long. Those opera people are funny. They wanted me to put up $180,000.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: What about it, Mr. Deeds?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Why, I turned them down, naturally.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: No, I mean - about my client.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh - we'll have to do something about the common wife.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Of course, we don't want to appear greedy, Mr. Deeds.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: I say we don't want to appear greedy.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh. That.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Mrs. Semple is entitled by law to one-third of the estate.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: And don't ever get down on your knees again, understand?

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Mrs. Semple is entitled to one- third of the estate.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: One-third? That's about $7,000,000 isn't it?

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Well, we didn't expect that much. I'm sure I can get her to settle quietly for one million.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: You're making a mistake, Mr. Deeds.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh no, I'm not. I don't like your face. Besides, there's something fishy about a person who would settle for a million dollars when they can get seven million. I'm surprised that Mr. Cedar, who's supposed to be a smart man, couldn't see through that.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: Now wait a minute, buddy

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: There's one nice thing about being rich - you ring a bell and things happen. When the servant comes in, Mr. Hallor, I'm going to ask him to show you to the door. Many people don't know where it is.

turns.speaker: HALLOR
turns.text: No use in getting tough. That'll get you nowhere, Mr. Deeds.  You know, we've got letters.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: No - I don't want it, thank you.

turns.speaker: HENABERRY
turns.text: Why, you must drink! All poets drink!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, I don't know. I

turns.speaker: HENABERRY
turns.text: Mr. Morrow, over there, for instance, just dashes them off.

turns.speaker: HENABERRY
turns.text: Yes. Have you any peculiar characteristics when you are creating?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, I play the tuba.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HENABERRY
turns.text: You mean to tell me you don't carry a pocketful around with you?

turns.speaker: HENABERRY
turns.text: Look, he's temperamental.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yeah, what if I am? What about it?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Your Honor

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'd like to get in my two cents' worth.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Take the stand!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Proceed.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, I don't know where to begin. There's been so many things said about me that I

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: An O-filler. You fill in all the spaces in the O's, with your pencil.  I was watching you.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Deeds, do you recall forcibly ejecting people from your home?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, yes. Yes. About my throwing those people out of my house. Mrs. Pomponi told the truth. I did throw them out because I didn't want the party in the first place. I didn't invite anybody. Mrs. Pomponi did all that. They just came to see what kind of a freak the "Cinderella Man" was. I don't know how people like that are supposed to act, Your Honor, but if that Pomponi woman is an example, I'll stick to simple folks. She just came in, talked my ear off, and took charge of everything. If I were a friend of hers, I'd have her examined.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Now about the Falkner sisters. That's kind of funny. I mean about Mr. Cedar going all the way to Mandrake Falls to bring them here. Do you mind if I talk to them?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Deeds, you haven't yet touched upon a most important thing. This rather fantastic idea of yours to want to give away your entire fortune. It is, to say the least, most uncommon.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh yes, I was getting to that, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Please, Mr. Cedar!  Proceed.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Personally, I don't know what Mr. Cedar's raving about. From what I can see, no matter what system of government we have, there will always be leaders and always be followers.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Anything else, Mr. Deeds?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: No.  Yes. There's just one more thing I'd like to get off my chest before I finish.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Proceed.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Huh? On, no. Nobody important.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Be sure and point 'em out to me, won't you?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'm a writer myself, you know.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I write poetry.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Brookfield just came in.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, the poet? Where?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Over at that big round table. The one that looks like a poodle.

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: Say fellow, you neglected me - and I feel very put out.  Look, sock it right there, will you? Lay one right on the button,[6] but sock it hard.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That's all right. I got it off my chest.

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: The difference between them and me is I know when I've been a skunk. You take me to the nearest news- stand and I'll eat a pack of your postcards raw. Raw!

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: Oh, what a magnificent deflation of smugness. Pal, you've added ten years to my life!  A poet with a straight left and a right hook - delicious! Delicious!  You're my guest from now on - forever and a day - even unto eternity!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Thanks, but Miss Dawson and I are going out to see the sights.

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: Fine, fine. Swell, You just showed me a sight lovely to behold, and I'd like to reciprocate. Listen, you hop aboard my magic carpet  thanks - and I'll show you sights that you've never seen before.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'd kind of like to see Grant's Tomb - and the Statue of Liberty.

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: Well, you'll not only see those, but before the evening's half through, you'll be leaning against the Leaning Tower of Pisa - you'll mount Mt. Everest. I'll show you the Pyramids and all the little Pyramiddes, leaping from sphinx to sphinx. Pal, how would you like to go on a real, old-fashioned binge?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Binge?

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: Yes. I mean the real McCoy. Listen, you play saloon with me, and I'll introduce you to every wit, every nit-wit, and every half-wit in New York. We'll go on a twister that'll make Omar the soused philosopher of Persia[7] look like an anemic on a goat's milk diet.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That ought to be fun.

turns.speaker: MORROW
turns.text: Fun?  Say, listen, I'll take you on a bender that will live in your memory as a thing of beauty and joy forever.  Boy! Boy! My headpiece!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Who are they?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: New mouthpiece. Been waiting two weeks for this. Kids keep swiping them all the time. They use 'em for bean shooters.  What can I do for you gentlemen?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: You gentlemen going to stay for lunch?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: How about lunch? Are the gentlemen going to stay - or not?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Of course they're going to stay.  She's got some fresh orange layer cake. You know, with the thick stuff on the top?  Sure, they don't want to go to the hotel.

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: No, he's too fussy for that. That's what's the matter with him. There are lots of nice girls right here in Mandrake Falls who're dying to be married

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Don't pay any attention to her.

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: He's got a lot of foolish notions - about saving a lady in distress.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Now you keep out of this!

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: Well, we could borrow a couple from Mrs. Simpson. You know, she went to Niagara Falls last year.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'm kind of nervous. I've never been away from Mandrake Falls in my life. Kind of like to see Grant's Tomb, though.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Hear what he said? You know how much twenty million is?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: I don't care how much it is. You sit right there and eat your lunch. You haven't touched a thing.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What is your name?

turns.speaker: SVENSON
turns.text: Christian Svenson.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Farmer?

turns.speaker: SVENSON
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Where is your farm?

turns.speaker: SVENSON
turns.text: South Dakota north.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: South Dakota - north?

turns.speaker: SVENSON
turns.text: South Dakota - but on the top.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh. Oh!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You're Mabel - her sister - aren't you?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Huh? Oh, yes - yes, of course. Her sister. Yes, I've been her sister for a long time.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Is she home?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Yeah. What?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Is Mary home?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: You mean  by the neck or something?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sure. They got on my nerves, so I threw 'em out.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Nice day out - er, nice night - wasn't it? - isn't it?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Yes, lovely. We've had a lot of nice weather lately.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: It would be a nice night to go for a walk, don't you think?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Oh yes, I think it'd be a swell night to go for a walk. A nice long one.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Goodnight. Don't worry. I won't keep her out late.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Thank you so much. Good night.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Tails tonight, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What - tails?  Why, that's a monkey suit![5] Do you want people to laugh at me?  I never wore one of those things in my life.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What do you think you're doing?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Why, I'm assisting you, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Get up from there. I don't want anybody holding the ends of my pants. Get up from there!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Imagine that - holding the ends of my pants!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Excuse me. What did you say?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He talks about women as if they were cattle.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Every man to his taste, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Tell me, Walter, are all those stories I hear about my uncle true?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Well, sir, he sometimes had as many as twenty in the house at the same time.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Twenty! What did he do with them?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: That was something I was never able to find out, sir.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Mr. Deeds - Mr. Deeds, sir - you really must get up. It's late!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You're Walter, aren't you?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I just wanted to make sure.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: A Prairie Oyster, sir.[10]

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Prairie? Oysters?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir. It makes the head feel smaller.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh. Oh!  Has Miss Dawson called yet?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Miss Dawson, sir? No, sir. No Miss Dawson has called, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: She was a lady in distress. She wouldn't let me help her. Got a lot of pride. I like that.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Oh, I do too, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I'd better call her up and apologize. I don't remember taking her home last night.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'd venture to say, sir, you don't remember much of anything that happened last night, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What do you mean? I remember everything!  Hand me my pants - I wrote her phone number on a piece of paper.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You have no pants, sir.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You came home last night - without them.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I did what!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: As a matter of fact, you came home without any clothes. You were in your - uh - shorts. Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, don't be silly, Walter. I couldn't walk around in the streets without any clothes. I'd be arrested.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: That's what the two policemen said, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What two policemen?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: The ones who brought you home, sir. They said you and another gentleman kept walking up and down the streets, shouting: "Back to nature! Clothes are a blight on civilization! Back to nature!"

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Please!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: But how'll I put on the slipper, sir?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir. I beg pardon, sir, but did you ever find what you were looking for, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Looking for?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You kept searching me last night, sir. Going through my pockets. You said you were looking for a rhyme for Budington.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Better bring me some coffee, Walter.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Very good, sir.  Oh, I beg pardon. A telegram came for you, sir.  I'll get you some black coffee, sir.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Madame Pomponi is on the telephone, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Madame Pomponi. She says everything is all set for the reception.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What do you mean by coming in here when I'm playing?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: But she's on the telephone

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Get out.  The evil finger's on you. Get out!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Hey, did you hear that?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What, sir?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Why, that's an echo, sir!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You try it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Me, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir. What is it, sir? Anything happened3

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Anything happened? I've got to get dressed! I can't meet her like this!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: But she isn't due for an hour, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: An hour? What's an hour! You know how time flies, Walter. My tie? Get it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir. Very good, sir. Here it is right here, sir. There, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Pack my things, Walter. I'm going home.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Shall I call the police, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: No!  What do you want!!

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: What do they want from me?  What have I done that's so wrong?  They act as though they don't have their own peculiar things... They do! Believe me. Everybody's got something...  Even you probably have things.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Me more than most.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: Why are they ganging up against me?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: I'm not sure. But I think they're worried about you.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: It's the kids, you know, not Jeremy. He had nothing to do with this -- except pay, of course. He's always willing to pay. He's extremely generous.  I'm so humiliated that my own children would threaten me.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: How did they threaten you?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: They said if I didn't get help, they wouldn't deal with me any more.  What do you think about that?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Good kids.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: Mmmmfffstttubll abbittmm.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Hmm?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: I said... you must come out to the house for dinner on Thursday.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Really? You think so?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: Yes. Jeremy will be home for the weekend. And you can meet the kids.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: -- The argument had nothing to do with it.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: I understand. I just want to know what the argument was about.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: I had ordered some books. "The 100 Greatest Books Ever Written."

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Uh-huh. What are they?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: Oh, all the great writers -- Shakespeare, Charles Dickens, Moby Dick... those people. Each is bound in genuine premium leather with 22 carat gold accents. It's a magnificent set -- and only $33.50 per volume. Right away you get Great Expectations for just $6.99.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: One hundred books?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: It's irrelevant. It had nothing to do with what happened.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: We argued on Sunday. He went to work on Monday and stayed in the city during the week, like always. But on Thursday, when he normally comes home, he didn't. Didn't call either. Not till Saturday afternoon.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: You must have been concerned.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: It's happened before.  I'm shocked by how little I'm feeling. I can't understand it.  I'll probably have a complete depressoid collapse soon, won't I?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Doubtful. What did he say?

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: He said he wasn't coming back. He said it wasn't working for him any more. That it hadn't "worked for him" for quite a while... You know what I regret the most? I'm sorry I let him make the kids take his name. He was an acquirer.  He liked to acquire things.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: I know my time's up, but I've got to get this out while I've got hold of it --

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Take your time.

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: -- When I was in high school, the thing I wanted most, when I was stuck in class, the thing I was always desperately in pursuit of -- was a hall pass. That's all I wanted. I loved moving freely around the school while everybody else was trapped in there... And that's how I feel right now... Like I have some giant, all- day hall pass.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: You can go out there if you like...

turns.speaker: ALTHEA
turns.text: "There's no shame in getting a little therapy", right, Doc?

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: Dr. Mumford.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Mr. Cook.

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: Could you come with me please?

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: I know I shoulda come to your office. I was gonna, actually, but then when you walked in here today...

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: It's my daughter Sofie... she's gotta problem.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: We're not sure. She's been to all kinds of doctors in the city and they've said different things. Some of 'em are callin' it --  -- Epstein-Barr virus, and the rest are callin' it... Chronic Fatigue Symptom...

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Syndrome... Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: That's it -- syndrome. So you know all about it?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: No... a little. There's a lot of debate about it.

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: Yeah, I got that. Some people think it's all in their heads.  It's been so bad she's had to move back here to Mumford and live with us. And I'm not sure that's the best thing, either...

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Why's that?

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: Oh... a lot of things. Several different factors. Will you see her, Doctor Mumford?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Sure. Why don't you bring her up to my office at 3 tomorrow afternoon.

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: I'm not sure she'll come. She's in a mood. Do you ever go to somebody's house?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Generally that doesn't work out so well. It sends the wrong message to people who need to make a change.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Cook. I was wondering if Sofie was around?

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: Were you supposed to have a session?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: No. It's sort of spur of the moment.

turns.speaker: COOK
turns.text: Her friend from the city came and took her out to dinner. First time in a long time she's been willing.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: A friend?

turns.speaker: CORRECTIONAL OFFICER
turns.text: Better make yourself comfortable. We got a three hour drive here.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: CORRECTIONAL OFFICER
turns.text: You're the shrink, aren't you?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: No, not really.

turns.speaker: CORRECTIONAL OFFICER
turns.text: But you do therapy?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Not any more.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: What an asshole!

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: Ernest, what do you think?

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: I think he's got a point.

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: You never got back to me.  ...I called to say we'd like to take you out for a meal?... Kind of a professional welcome.

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: What Ernest means, I think, is we're very interested in other methodology... different kinds of training. We're great believers in learning from each other. I've learned so much from Ern -- Dr. Delbanco...

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: ...And I from Phyllis.

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: So... the University of Kentucky. Who runs the program down there?

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: But they're certainly dead. And yes, personally, I find it a bit odd.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: It could happen. What about his state certification exams? The records seem to be in order.

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: You do seem much more disposed toward him than I understand, Ernest. Did I miss something?

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: Oh, for god's sake, Phyllis -- we have no reason to doubt the man! Are we listening to Lionel now?

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: Phyllis, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to shout...

turns.speaker: SHEELER
turns.text: No, Dr. Delbanco, it is I who am sorry. Sorry to have wasted your time with such...

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Dr. Delbanco. It's nice to see you again.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: I don't think you know Dr. Sheeler. She's the other therapist here in town.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Of course... I've heard great things about you.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: What are you doing for lunch?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Right now?

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: I've run on. Forgive me. We're here to talk about you.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Are we?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: My mentor was an amazing teacher named Benton Mandlebaum. Died quite tragically in the collapse of a gazebo.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: I think I've heard of him... a disciple of Rothberg, wasn't he?

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: Interesting approach. What was his name?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: Dorothy Fowler. Fantastic woman. She passed last year in a train wreck. Damned Amtrak.

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: We're interested in any new therapies. How would you characterize your approach?

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: My approach?

turns.speaker: DELBANCO
turns.text: ...I won't go into that today. Though, if we should continue these sessions, as I certainly hope we will, there are some aspects of that I would like to look at. God knows, I've listened to enough people giving me the juicy --  ...At any rate, I just wanted to acknowledge the catalyzing effect your comment had on me. I just hope that it doesn't come roiling back upon you like some dreadful undertow.

turns.speaker: MUMFORD
turns.text: How do you mean?
